Ganoderma applanatum has an ecological role. As a parasite, G. applanatum continues to digest the tree’s lignin. It can also grow as a saprophyte for many years. Lignin functions in water conduction and due to its hydrophobic properties, stops the tree from absorbing too much water. Since much of the tree’s lignin is used as food, G. applanatum weakens the tree.

Some fungi are edible and delicious. On the other hand, others are poisonous and toxic. While G. applanatum is probably not poisonous or toxic, it cannot really be considered edible due to the hyphae being too thick to consume.

The major function for G. applanatum is its ability to be used as a canvas. I am sure that it is not as often used to sketch on as it once was, but since it’s spore surface is easy to scratch off, drawings or writings can be created on it. Since this can occur, this fungus is called the artist’s conk.

http://botit.botany.wisc.edu/... align=right alt="Ganoderma art from TomVolkFungi.net">

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Called the scaly vase Chanterelle. This is a vase-shaped mushroom with a strongly depressed pileus that can range from 4-16 cm wide and up to 30 cm tall. However, 15 cm tall is the average. The upper surface of the pileus is a pale-orange to orange brown base covered in darker-orange to red-orange scales. However, with age, the scales can become more inconspicuous and the upper surface of the pileus can take on a more uniform color. The flesh is thick and fibrous. The underside of the pileus is a white to cream color, darkening with age, with strongly decurrent, blunt ridges that fork, superficially similar to the blunt ridges of true chanterelles. The stipe is hard to separate from the pileus but can be up to 10 cm long and up to 4 cm wide. Spore print is ochraceous to yellow-brown. Spore size can range from 11-20 × 6-10 micrometers. Spore shape can be referred to as elliptic with small warts and wrinkles. Can be found singly or in small clusters in mixed woods, seems to prefer hemlock. Thought to be ectomycorrhizal with conifers. A fairly common species that fruits from June-September.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Pileus that is very deeply depressed in the center. Dark/red-orange scales on upper surface can be very distinguishing if present. White to cream colored blunt, forked ridges that run from nearly top to bottom.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Having a fairly cosmopolitan distribution in the Northern Hemisphere, this species can be found throughout the northern and montane regions of North America. Most abundant in the moist parts of the Pacific Northwest. This species has also been observed throughout Asia including: Korea, China, Tibet, Nepal, India, and Pakistan.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Fairly common in North America, preferring northern and montane regions in moist habitats. Most common in mixed forests with large concentrations of conifers. Thought to form an ectomycorrhizal relationships with various conifers including: Pseudotsuga, Abies, Pinus and Tsuga heterophylla.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Can be confused with Gomphus kauffmanii. However, G. kauffmanii are a lot more rare and have numerous erect, dark brown scales on top of a tan to cinnamon-colored base. Also, the stem of G. kauffmanii stains pinkish-purple when bruised.

Can also be confused with the edible chanterelle, Cantharellus cibarius and related Cantharellus species. However, the upper surface of the pileus of C. cibarius is not nearly as deeply depressed in the center and could almost be considered planar. C. cibarius also has an incurved margin.

See Tom Volk’s page on chanterelles

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Not recommended as an edible. Can be enjoyed by some but for most can cause gastrointestinal upset.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Grifola frondosa photo courtesy of MushroomObserver.org, 2008, MushroomObserver.org

Commonly known as Sheep’s Head, Hen of the Woods, or Maitake, Grifola frondosa is an edible species that grows at the foot of trees, particularly oak trees, in clusters of gray-brown caps which are generally curled or contorted in some manner and originate from a single branched stem structure (1), (2), (4).

See Tom Volk’s page on Grifola frondosa

(2)

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Cluster: 15-60cm broad or more, very large, sometimes weighing in excess of 4 kg

Caps: 2-10cm width on individual caps, fan-shaped, gray-brown, curled or contorted, often with concentric zones and wavy margins

Pore surface: lavender-gray when young, turning dirty-white to yellowish with age while creeping down the stem, pores angular, 1-3 pores per mm

Stem: branched, smooth, white, tough, usually lateral

Flesh: firm, white, tough

Taste: mild

Odor: mild, nutty

Type of rot: white butt rot

Spores: spore print white, 5-7×3.5-5 micrometers, smooth, hyaline, broadly elliptical

Edibility: edible and choice

Hyphal Structure: trimitic, generative hyphae with clamp connections

(1), (2), (4), (5)

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Widely distributed east of the Rocky Mountains, rare in the west (2). Also found in eastern Asia and Europe.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Parasitic on hardwoods and conifers, often continuing as a saprophyte on dead trees. Fruits in large clusters of rosettes near the bases of trees,usually oaks (Quercus), often reappearing in the same place in subsequent years (2).

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Dendropolyporus umbellatus = Polyporus umbellatus form large, overlapping clusters of circular, whitish to pale brown, depressed caps with centrally attached branches on the ground near hardwoods (1).


Polyporus umbellatus photo courtesy of Michael Kuo, Nov. 2004, MushroomExpert.com (3)

Meripilus sumstinei is also similar, but with thicker, shelf-like caps and a white pore surface that bruises black (1).


Meripilus sumstinei photo courtesy of MushroomObserver.org, 2008, MushroomObserver.org

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
The species has been used in traditional Chinese Herbal Medicine for thousands of years as a treatment for spleen and stomach ailments, calming nerves and mind, treating hemorrhoids, cancer, palsy, nerve pain, and arthritis. More generally, the mushroom was used for general treatments for immune stimulation and regulation of homeostasis (4).

The Japanese common name, maitake, means “dancing mushroom,” because when someone finds one they are inclined to do a dance of joy.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Gymnopus dryophilus is a small brown capped mushroom which is often considered to be a weed by many due to the fact that it is so common. It was formerly known as Collybia dryophila.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Macroscopic Features

Cap: 1-7.5 cm, convex with an incurved margin when young, becoming broadly convex to flat; moist; smooth; dark reddish brown to brown when young, becoming tan to orangish brown to very pale.
Gills: Attached to the stem or free from it; whitish to pinkish, becoming buff; crowded.
Stem: 1-10 cm long; 2-7 mm thick; equal, occasionally slightly flared to base; dry; pliant and fibrous; smooth; whitish above, light buff below, becoming darker; soon hollow; usually with thin, whitish rhizomorphs attached to the base.
Spore Print: White to creamy or pale yellowish white.

Microscopic Features

Spores: 5-6.5 × 2.5-3.5 µ, smooth, elliptical, inamyloid.
Cheilocystidia 15-50 × 2-6 µ, clavate, subclavate, cylindric, or irregular; often with lobes or coralloid projections.
Hyphae:branched and swollen, interwoven hyphae 2-13 µ wide.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Despite its name which translates as “oak-loving”, this mushroom will grow almost anywhere in hardwood or conifer forest. Frequently on twigs or leaf litter, it is often found in the spring, summer, and fall and in winter in warmer climates.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: Many of the Gymnopus and Rhodocollybia species often look like Gymnopus dryophilus at first glance. Many times microscopic studies are required to determine what the species is.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Some studies have shown that certain chemicals formed by this fungus could be used as an anti-inflammatory agent although it is mostly just thought of as a weed.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common name: Tender Nesting Polypore

Hapalopilus nidulans is a tan/ ochraceous polypore mushroom with white basidiospores. It is found growing on hardwoods or conifers during spring to fall and is a wood decaying saprophyte. The shelf-like fruiting body has no stem and is a convex kidney shape with fine hairs. Normal size is 5 to 15 cm across, 2-4 cm wide, and 1-4 cm thick. The pore surface and flesh are the same color as the pileus top. The flesh is soft/spongy and watery at first, but will dry tough and hard. Spores are white, elliptical/cylindrical, and smooth with sizes ranging from 3.5-5 × 2-3 µm. Pores are angular and 2-4 per mm. The hyphal system is monomitic with thick to thin walled generative hyphae that have clamp connections. Seasonality is annual, completing its fruiting in one season. H. nidulans is not edible, but it is not known to be poisonous. One fun characteristic is that the flesh will turn a deep lilac purple when exposed to KOH.

It was formerly called Polyporus nidulans and a synonym is Hapalopilus rutilans.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: The easiest way to identify Hapalopilus nidulans is to use 3% KOH and observe the intense violaceous color, but it can be identified by its small (3.5-5 × 2-3 µm) smooth, white spores and its monomitic hyphal system. The thick to thin generative hyphae have clamp connections. The fruiting body is no more than 15 cm wide.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Southwest North America to eastern North America. Europe.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Hapalopilus nidulans is a wood decay fungus that grows on dead hardwood or conifer debris. It is found growing on conifer debris in southwest North America, or on hardwood debris in eastern North America. It has also been found in Europe.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Hapalopilus croceus is much larger, up to 20.5 cm wide. It has a reddish orange pore surface but stains bright red in KOH, not purple.

Phellinus gilvus has a rusty yellow top and flesh that is tough and fibrous. It has a dark brown spore-bearing poroid surface, and the flesh stains dark brown in KOH. It also has setae that are characteristic of the family Hymenochaetaceae, not Polyporaceae.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
Hapalopilus nidulans is useful for dyeing wool and can produce a bright lilac color. Mordants such as alum (aluminum potassium sulfate) are useful to control different shades or color.

See this page and this page for more information about dyeing wool and other natural fabrics with fungi

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Haploporus odorus is a perennial hoof-shaped polypore found north of 52 degrees north latitude. There are historical records of its use by the Northern plains native Americans, however observations of this polypore has been limited to British Columbia in North American and northwestern parts of Europe. It grows on Salix sp. (willows) as a high sitting shelf in humid conditions in forest dominated by conifers. This polypore is a white-rot fungus. It has a pale buff to black pileus and a white lower pore layer. The unique features found with H. odorus are the strong smell of aniseed that persists even after drying and dextrinoid spores that are minutely ornamented or echinulated.
Alternate names: Polyporus odorus, Fomitopsis odora, and Trametes odora.

Photo by Irene Andersson on http://mushroomobserver.org>Mushroom Observer

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Haploporus odorus forms a perennial basidiocarp. You will find it growing almost exclusively on Salix spp. in a sessile or effused-reflexed manner. The pileus is pale buff, darkening with age to a darker dingy brown to black coloration. They can be finely tomentose to almost glabrous and will grow up to 6 × 15 × 8 cm in size. The pore surface is pale buff in color, smooth, corky, faintly zonate, up to 7 cm thick. Pores are 4-5 per mm and circular.
Hyphal system is trimitic; the generative hyphae have clamps, are thin-walled, rarely branched and are 2-3.5 um in diameter; the skeletal hyphae are nonseptate, hyaline, rarely branched and are 3-5 um in diameter; the binding hyphae are thick-walled, 1.5-2.5 um in diameter, nonseptate, hyaline and are very branched.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Haploporus odorus is found north of 52 degrees North latitude in circumglobal Boreal regions. In North America there have been 20 records from British Columbia, with only 4 in the past 20 years. H. odorus a typical taiga species. It grows in swampy coniferous subarctic forest extending south from the tundra. In Europe it is found most commonly in northeastern Sweden, Finland, North Western Russia, a few locations in southeast Norway, Estonia, and Poland.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Haploporus odorus is a typical taiga species growing in swampy coniferous subarctic forest extending south from the tundra. It grows almost exclusively on living Salix caprea causing a white-rot decay to occur.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Trametes suaveolens is the only other polypore with a similar macroscopic appearance and odor of anise. However, with T. suaveolens the odor does not remain after drying. T. suaveolens has an average of 1-3 pores per mm and _Haploporus odorus has 4-5 per mm. Microscopically T. suaveolens spores are 7-11 X 3-4 um, while H. odorus has spores measuring 5-6.5 X 3-4.5 um that are distinctly echinulate and slightly dextrinoid. The hyphae of T. suaveolens are thick walled with the absence of cross walls or clamps and are 6-12 um in diameter. H. odorus hyphae will have clamps.
The distribution for T. suaveolens is more southern and includes southern Europe, Ontario and Alberta, Canada and as far south as Iowa and Kansas in the United States. H. odorus is found most commonly in northeastern Sweden, Finland, western Russia, a few locations in southeast Norway, Estonia, and Poland in Europe. In North America H. odorus remains only in a few scattered localities in Canada.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
Haploporus odorus has been and still is considered to be a sacred fungus by the northern plains Native American cultures. It is a symbol of spiritual power. The Blackfoot, Blood, Cree are a few of the Indigenous Peoples of the northern American plains that used H. odorus as part of their ornamentation of sacred objects and for medicinal purposes. It was used on sacred robes, necklaces, other cultural properties as well as a component of medicine bundles. The strong anise-like scent produced by H. odorus seems to be the reason for the reverence of this fungus. H. odorus has been found in collections dating back to the 1800s.
The historical information has been sketchy due to incorrect identification, the loss of information passed on by Native American cultures and even an apprehension to discuss fungi for fear of being taboo. Museum articles have been incorrectly labeled as carved cottonwood roots, puffball fungi or the basidiocarp of Fomitopsis officinalis.

The Cree word for H. odorus is “Wikmasigan” according to Creehealer Russedll Willier and is said it “opens the door to the spirit world and allows me to see and hear the spirits.” H. odorus has been used to ward off respiratory diseases and ghosts. It is used in purification rituals as a smudge or an incense.

Blanchette, R. A. 1997. Haploporus odorus: A sacred fungus in traditional Native American culture of the northern plains. Mycologia.89(2): 233-240.

taxon.reference: Atti Soc. Ital. Sc. Nat. Milano 11: 613 (1868) emend Poelt, Nova Hedwigia 9:31 (1965)

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common name: Fringe or Centipede Lichens (temperate species), or Shield Lichens (tropical species)
Family: Physciaceae

Relatively small or narrow-lobed foliose lichens, typically light gray (“atranorin gray”) and dull. In temperate North America, they are typically almost fruticose in appearance with abundant long cilia, and cottony below from lack of cortex.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Upper Surface: K+ yellow (atranorin), prosoplectenchymatous, with or without pruina or cilia
Lower Surface: often decorticate, generally pale, prosoplectenchymatous
Algae: green (trebouxioid)
Reproduction: apothecia, soredia, or isidia
Spores: physcioid (thick-walled, not Physconia-type)

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Mostly pantropical, but some extending north into the temperate.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Generally on bark or wood, though rarely on rock or soil (which?).

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Physcia: some Physcia, such as P. tenella and to a lesser extent P. adscendens, can also have cilia, but lower cortex always present (when not eroded into soredia), and upper cortex paraplectenchymatous. Heterodermia generally grow free from the surface, though see H. hypoleuca for example.

Other Physciaceae are K-.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: This species is a somewhat large, flat polypore fungus that grows on dead wood. Usually with an effused-reflexed basidiocarp. If a stipe is present it appears laterally. It has a semi-circular shape that can reach 3-19 cm broad, 2.5-10 cm wide and 0.2-1 cm thick. Flesh is hard and firm and has faint concentric zones on top. The underside is light grey/brown and flat to slightly undulating. The brown to gray pores can be up to 3mm long and there are approximately 4 per mm. The hyphal system is trimitic and clamps are present. Cystitis are absent. Cavite basidia that are 25-35 × 7-9 micrometers. Thin-walled spores are hyaline, cylindrical and 11-14.5 × 3.5-5 micrometers. The top of the basidiocarp has a very distinguishing characteristic; it is covered in a dense coating of dark-brown/black bristles that can be up to 5mm long, sometimes longer. The basidiocarp darkens in the presence of KOH.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: The upper surface of the basidiocarp is unique. It is covered in a dense mat of dark-brown/black bristles that can be 5mm in length or longer.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: This is a subtropical species that can be found throughout Central America, mostly Mexico and Costa Rica. Has also been known to occur in parts of South America and the West Indies. Has also been documented in South Africa and Kenya. In the United States it can only be found in Florida where it is actually quite common.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Causes white rot of dead wood. Found on dead and decaying wood of dogwood, figs and tamarind trees. Has also been reported on mahogany and Eugenia species. Found on a wide variety of hardwoods in Florida. Seems to prefer “soft wood,” but not conifers.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: Very distinct. Other Hexagonia species are not bristly on top.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
Currently Hexagonia hydnoidea is of no importance to humans. But you never know…

It is helpful in nature to decay wood and return nutrients to the ecosystem.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common name: Shadowcrust Lichens
Family: Physciaceae

Small, narrow-lobed nearly-crustose lichens, grayish to brownish and dull, with few or no rhizines.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Upper Surface: K-, paraplectenchymatous
Lower Surface: prosoplectenchymatous if present
Reproduction: apothecia, soredia, or isidia
Spores: physcioid (thick-walled, not Physconia-type)

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Bark and wood, rarely moss over rock.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: All other Physciaceae are either truly and obviously crustose, or less closely-appressed with well-developed rhizines.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Common Clam Lichen

Brownish squamulose lichen typically growing in vast colonies on charred wood. Usualy found without apothecia, and with powdery soredia underneath and along margins. Squamules generally lift from the substrate on their lower side, making them look a little like shingles.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: brownish to grayish-greenish, usually loosely-attached and strongly convex, squamules up to 1-2 mm wide
SOREDIA: powdery labriform soralia at or just under the free margins
APOTHECIA: rare, black, lecideine
CHEMISTRY: thallus conspicuously C+ and KC+ red (lecanoric acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Typically on the base of scorched conifers or other charred wood, but also on any acidic bark, especially in dry conifer forests that experience frequent mild burns.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
There are several brownish squamulose lichens, however few are C+ red.

H. anthracophila C-, PD+r
H. castaneocinerea C-, PD-
_H. sierrae C-, K+y
H. friesii not sorediate
H. oligospora not sorediate

Several other squamulose genera might be mistaken for Hypocenomyce as well…

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Sierras Clam Lichen

Grayish, sorediate squamulose lichen on conifer trunks and wood. Squamules generally lift from the substrate on their lower side, making them look a little like shingles.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: grayish to greenish-brown, usually loosely-attached and crenulate, squamules up to 0.7 mm wide
SOREDIA: powdery labriform soralia at or just under the free margins
APOTHECIA: uncommon, black, lecideine
CHEMISTRY: thallus K+ deep yellow (thamnolic acid), C+/- and KC+/- red (often with alectorialic acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: North America. Locally common in southern California.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Conifer bark and wood, especially Libocedrus and Sequoiadendron, apparently.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
There are several squamulose Hypocenomyce that are of varying similarity to this species, many best distinguished by chemistry:

H. oligospora squamules more adnate, never sorediate
H. scalaris browner, larger squamules, K-, always C+r
H. anthracophila K-, PD+r
H. castaneocinerea K-, PD-
H. friesii K-, not sorediate

Several other squamulose genera might be mistaken for Hypocenomyce as well…

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Irpex lacteus is in the phylum Basidiomycota, class Hymenomycetes, order Aphyllorphorales, family Polyporaceae and genus Irpex. Common name is “Milk-white Toothed Polypore.” Fruiting body is effused-reflexed growing on the underside of fallen hardwoods. Fruiting body appears to be similar in color to milk, but may range from white, to off-white or cream colored. Pores that break up into short teeth (less than 3 mm long) when mature. Fruiting body is dry and stiff (Bessette et al.).

Pictures:



Picture of Irpex lacteus from messiah.edu



Photo by William Tannenberger

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Irpex lacteus is the only species in the genus Irpex. To identify the genus; if the teeth are less than 3 mm in length (Irpex), if teeth are longer than 3 mm in length when mature you may have Spongipellis pachyodon. Irpex is a saprophyte on hardwoods and infrequently conifers causing white rot, but maybe parasitic on Cherry trees. Spore print white with spores ranging from 5-7 × 2-3 um that are smooth, cylindrical and inamyloid (Bessette et al.).

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Distributed across North America but very rare in the Southwest. Also known from Europe and elsewhere.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: It is found on the underside of fallen hardwoods, rarely on conifers, where it is a white rot saprophyte. It may be parasitic on Cherry trees.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Essentially no look alikes because it is the only species in the genus Irpex and the two characteristics, effused-reflexed and teeth less than 3 mm, make this species very easy to identify. Spongipellis pachyodon is a toothed polypore that looks somewhat similar but the teeth are usually longer than 3 mm in length.

<img src=“http://www.mushroomobserver.org/... />

Picture by James V. Gallagher IV

Schizopora paradoxa may sometimes look similar, but it is more poroid, and its hyphae have clamp connections.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
Irpex lacteus is inedible and isn’t commonly used by people.

However, it is an important saprophye in nature, returning nutrients back to the ecosystem.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Ischnoderma resinosum (Fr.) Karst. is a polypore common in the North American hardwood forests. It is easily identifiable upon a detailed inspection. When fresh, it is a characteristically soft polypore with a notably velvet like texture on the top portion of its cap. The vast majority of specimens are fan shaped on decaying hardwoods with caps that can range from 3-10”. The velvety top surface has notable zones/rings that radiate outward from the point of attachment. Young specimens are distinctly moist and will seep water when crushed. Distinct from other polypores, Ischnoderma resinosum is very fleshy especially when young. The spore bearing underside is white but quickly turns brown and bruises with slight pressure. As the specimen becomes larger and ages, it quickly becomes tough with a leather like texture similar to other polypores.
Common name: Resinous Polypore

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Identification of this species is easy with close examination. The fungus grows a shelf like cap similar to many other polypores. The top surface is brown to dark brown with traces of dark orange. The underside is a very clean white bruising easily to dark tan/brown when contacted with mild pressure. Ischnoderma resinosum spores leave an off whitish print. The spores are hyaline and cylindric/sausage like with sizes ranging from 4.5-7 × 1.5-2.5μm. The cap will slowly turn a dark gray/black with application of 3% KOH.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Ischnoderma resinosum is found in moderate hardwood forests throughout North America. It grows primarily on fallen hardwoods. It is generally not found on heavily decayed logs.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Ischnoderma resinosum is restricted to growing on dead hardwoods. Generally this species favors 1-2 year old logs as opposed to freshly fallen trees.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: Ischnoderma resinosum is commonly mistaken in Europe with Ischnoderma benzoinus, which is found to grow on conifers. The two are separated by many mycologists with Ischnoderma resinosum’s significantly darker flesh on the top of the fruiting body.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Ischnoderma resinosum currently has no practical industrial use. However it is an important part in the decay of many dead hardwoods, especially ~2 years after their death. It is considered to be inedible by many. However, the younger specimens can be consumed and are enjoyed by some people. For human consumption the younger fungi are chosen simply due to their softer texture.

taxon.dwc:ScientificName: Kjeldsenia aureispora W. Colgan, Castellano & Bougher

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: The truffle Kjeldsenia aureispora was named in honor of SOMA (SOnoma Mycological Association) co-founder, Dr. Chris Kjeldsen. It is an unusual genus that has a white outside peridium that stains yellow then turns reddish brown upon handling. It is placed in the family Cortinariaceae and is thought to be close to Hymenogaster. This is a photo of the holotype that was collected on Hwy 20 in Mendocino County, CA and published by one of Dr. Kjeldsen’s former students, Dr. Wes Colgan III.
Kjeldsenia aureispora W. Colgan, Castellano & Bougher

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Grows individually or in clumps on wood. Clumps in fan-like shapes, growing up to 60cm. Smooth to slightly wavy edges. Bright orange or yellow when young, fading with age. Not gilled, but a polypore with yellowish-white spores on its underside. Spore size: 5-7×3.5-5um. Flesh is thick and moist when young, becoming drier with age.

Commonly called the sulphur shelf, chicken of the woods, chicken fungus, or chicken mushroom.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Laetiporus sulphureus has yellow pores and grows from the “butt” of hardwoods, at the base of the tree or farther away. L. gilbertsonii is found in the coastal western US on Eucalyptus and on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico. It is indistinguishable from L. sulphureus, but they don’t mate in culture. L. conifericola grows in the western US on living and dead conifers. L. huronensis grows in the great lakes region on eastern hemlock in the spring. L. cincinnatus has white pores and grows primarily from soil, parasitic on the roots of trees.

See Tom Volk’s page on Laetiporus

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description:
Common in North America east of the Rocky Mountains. It is also distributed in northern Europe. Usually found in late summer and fall.

More work is being done on the Laetiporus species from other continents. Laetiporus sulphureus at least is known from Europe.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Parasitic and saprobic, growing on decaying hardwoods and conifers. It especially likes oaks, but can parasitize living trees in the right conditions.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
L. sulphureus isn’t difficult to identify with a little effort, and there are no other species known resembling L. sulphureus that can hurt you.

Other Laetiporus species can be distinguished as above.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Tastes like chicken! Chicken of the woods (Sulfur shelf) is pursued for its edibility. It can be prepared most ways you would make chicken. Vegetarians use it as a meat substitute. It needs to be cooked well before eating, just like real chicken, or stomach upset may follow.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Crustose lichen, forming striking, beautiful, greenish, lobate rosettes (sometimes confluent with nearby thalli) on most kinds of rock. At first closely-appressed, but in age the center buckles out and often comes off the rock completely. Abundant brownish to yellowish to orangish to greenish apothecia (often variably colored on the same thallus) packed tightly in the center. Lobe tips are somewhat thickened around the edge making them look a bit concave. Typically waxy in appearance, although it can be pruinose esp. near the tips. Though technically crustose, they often form a rudimentary lower cortex near the lobe tips, making them “honorary foliose” lichens.

One of the few (of many many) Lecanora that can be more-or-less reliably identified in the field. It is, however, a rather variable species, with several subspecies and varieties defined throughout the world. It can be non-pruinose or heavily pruinose, gray or greenish or yellowish, abundantly fertile or sparsely so, with strongly radiating or randomly overlapping lobes, and has light-colored but extremely variably-colored apothecia.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
LOBES: distinctly lobate, lobes plane to concave, grayish to pale yellowish-green to pale greenish-yellow, shiny-waxy texture, epruinose or not
ANATOMY: medulla loose and cottony, algal layer discontinuous
APOTHECIA: packed in center, discs pale yellowish to orangish to brownish, epruinoes; rim distinct, continuous, like thallus
CHEMISTRY: cortex usually KC+ gold (usnic acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Worldwide, cosmopolitan, often one of few lichens thriving in or near cities.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Most kinds of rock, in exposed situations, esp. enriched by birds, drip-zones, etc.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Other relatively-common, strongly-lobate, rosette-forming Lecanora:

L. garovaglii: lobes typically wider and thicker with a folded or inflated appearance
L. sierrae: lobes also wider and thicker, typically yellower
L. mellea and L. pseudomellea: brown or brownish
L. novomexicana: pruinose apothecia
L. phaedrophthalma: less distinctly lobate, darker apothecia?
L. bipruinosa: pruinose apothecia
L. valesiaca: thallus heavily pruinose, weakly separated lobes

Among several others…

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Brown-Eyed Wolf Lichen

Bright yellow shrubby fruticose lichen on conifers in montane forests. Looks like a yellow moss from a distance, often covering the entire northern side of a tree.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: bright yellow to greenish yellow, irregularly angled branches
ISIDIA: occasionally abundant
APOTHECIA: common, deep brown cups with yellow “eye-lashes”
PYCNIDIA: black, common
CHEMISTRY: K- (vulpinic acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Open conifer forests in mountains. On both bark and wood, often growing high up.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
The only thing that looks anything like it is L. vulpina, with which it often grows. L. vulpina is rarely apotheciate or pycnidiate, and always has abundant soredia or isidioid soredia. Since L. columbianum can have isidia, and L. vulpina can have apothecia and pycnidia, it is important to look at all three characteristics and their relative abundance. There is no overlap between the species when all three characteristics are considered together.

To further complicate things, it seems likely from recent work that there are actually several species involved in each of these two species, so it might be better to call them L. columbianum s. lato and L. vulpina s. lato.

The genus Vulpicida has a very similar color and the same chemistry, but it is distinctly foliose and has yellow medulla.

Other yellow or orange fruticose genera (e.g. Teloschistes) are oranger and K+ deep wine red from anthraquinones.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Common Wolf Lichen

Bright yellow shrubby fruticose lichen on conifers in montane forests. Looks like a yellow moss from a distance, often covering the entire northern side of a tree.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: bright yellow to greenish yellow, irregularly angled branches
SOREDIA: abundant, often appearing isidioid but cortex clearly eroded
APOTHECIA: rare, deep brown cups
PYCNIDIA: rare, black
CHEMISTRY: K- (vulpinic acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Open conifer forests in mountains. On both bark and wood, often growing high up.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: The only thing that looks anything like it is L. columbianum, with which it often grows. See the discussion under that species for differences between these two species and other yellow genera.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Leucopaxillus albissimus is a medium or at times large sized mushroom that is mycorrhizal with conifers or sometime eucalyptus. Some say it may be found decomposing the debris of conifers, but this is unconfirmed. The color of the cap or pileus of this mushroom varies and may be anywhere from white to buff, pinkish, pale brownish to pale tan.
The gills are pale yellowish to white in color are easily separated from the cap as a layer. The base of the stipe has a dense white mycelium.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Pileus: The Cap is about 3-20 cm broad and the margin is convex and rolled inwardly initially, which later appear convex or depressed. The cap is dry and smooth. It has a velvety texture. The color varies very widely from white to brown and darkens with age at times. The flesh of the gills is a little thick. The odor is mild and has an unpleasant taste.

Gills: The Gills are attached to the stem, appear decurrent and the gills are easily separated from the cap as a layer. The color initially is white but turns buff with age.

Stipe: The stem or stipe is about 3-8 cm long, 2.3-4 cm thick, stout or swollen, enlarged at base when young and then becomes equal at maturity. The surface is smooth and may be finely scaled or hairy. It is white and has a dense mycelial growth at the base.

Odor and Taste: Odor is mild and not distinct or associated with any particular smell. Taste is unpleasant or bitter.

Spore Print: White.

Spores: The Size of the Spores ranges from 5-7 × 3.5-5 µm. They are elliptical, ornamented. They are amyloid. The spores appear spiny with warts which are about 0.4u.

Habitat: They are saprobic and are commonly found scattered, gregarious in arcs or rings, mostly under the debris of conifers.

Edibility: Inedible. Though the mushroom is not lethal or toxic, it has an unpleasant taste so it is not palatable.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: This mushroom is found widely distributed over North America and is also known to be found around Europe.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: It is known to occur mostly under conifers, and occassionally hardwoods too e.g. Monterey cypress (Cupressus macrocarpa), Monterey pine (Pinus radiata), Coast Redwood (Sequoia sempervirens), and Blue Gum (Eucalyptus globulus).

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: This mushroom is most likely to be confused with a deadly species of Clitocybe, or some Tricholoma spp. that look very similar. Thus caution must be exercised.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Members of the genus Leucopaxillus have been known to persist in the environment for a longer than normal time. This suggests that they are more resistant to bacterial degradation and production of antibiotics that make the mushrooms persist much longer than most.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Family: Ophioparmaceae

Light grayish, thin crustose lichens with brown lecanorine apothecia.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
SURFACE: K+ deep yellow, P+ orange (thamnolic acid)
APOTHECIA: brown (lighter if pruinose), lecanorine
ASCI: K/I+ tip with broad lighter axial mass
SPORES: 8 per ascus, hyaline, long and narrow with several transverse septa, often curved or twisted, spirally aranged in ascus

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: (In North America it appears to be confined to northeastern part of continent.)

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: There are several other crustose genera with lecanorine, brown apothecia, however most (e.g., Lecanora) have simple spores. Apparently only a few crustose genera have thamnolic acid (e.g., Pertusaria which has huge thick-walled spores).

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Family: Ophioparmaceae

Monotypic genus containing a single epiphytic crustose lichen. It is grayish and covered with long, slender, often branched isidia.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Hypermaritime region from northern California to southern Alaska, and the BC inland rainforest. Possibly also in other temperate rainforests around the world?

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: Nothing like it: no other crustose lichen has such long slender isidia.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Lycoperdon perlatum is roughly the shape of an inverted pear. The stem is fairly large and the top is rounded. 2.5-7 cm wide and 3-7.5 cm high. Small whitish warts cover the fruiting body when young, fall off with age and leave scars. A large perforation is found in the center of the puffball that facilitates spore dispersal via rain or wind. White and fleshy when young but changing eventually to an olive color with brown spore dust. Spores 3.5-4.5 um round, minutely spiny. Capillital threads olive in KOH (3-7um wide).

Interestingly the genus name Lycoperdon translates as “Wolf fart.”

See Tom Volk’s page on puffballs

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Lycoperdon pyriforme is similar, but almost always grows on wood.

Lycoperdon echinatum has a reddish tinge and is covered with spines. Lycoperdon mammiforme is white at first but breaks up into large cream scales rather than warts.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: The common puffball is located throughout America and Europe. In temperate regions it grows in the summer and fall. However, in warmer habitats like California and the Gulf of Mexico it grows nearly year round. Usually found in the woods, but also can be located on roadsides or urban areas.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Saprophytic, growing on ground near hardwoods or conifers. Solitary, scattered or in clumps.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
The genus Lycoperdon is distinguishable from the genus Scleroderma because it lacks a thick peridium and has a soft gleba (the internal portion where the spores are borne). In addition, Scleroderma has a dark gleba as compared to the white gleba of Lycoperdon. In addition, Scleroderma species are mycorrhizal, while Lycoperdon species are saprophytic.

Calvatia species are similar to Lycoperdon but are usually much larger.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
Lycoperdon perlatum is edible when young, but needs to be avoided after white color fades. It is delicious sautéed in olive oil and butter after being dipped in egg and bread crumbs.

Some native American cultures used puffball spores as a salve for wounds. This has been reported to speed healing.

However, there are several cases of lycoperdosis known from inhaling large quantities of spores.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Pileus: 1.5-3.5 cm broad, rounded, becoming broadly convex to nearly plane; margin becoming translucent-striate; surface moist, smooth, gray-brown to gray to grayish white often darken in towards the center; often developing darker tones where it has dried; flesh thick, reviving after being dried; odor and taste mild. Cap becoming distinctly wavy in age.

Lamellae: Adnexed to nearly free, subdistant to distant, interspersed with 1-2 series of lamellulae. May be lightly intervenose; color similar to cap, but typically a bit lighter.

Stipe: 2-5 cm tall, 2-6 mm thick, equal, can be compressed, tough, whitish to pale grayish, the base with short hairs (tomentose); veil absent.

Spore print: White.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Macroscopically Marasmius albogriseus is fairly distinct. The combination of the light-gray tones, wide-space lamellae, and tough texture are distinctive. It is similar in shape and stature to Marasmius oreades, but M. albogriseus has distinct gray tones and is more often found in leaf litter as opposed to the tan tones and lawn habitat of M. oreades. It would be possible to confuse this species with a gray Hygrophorus s.l., but those species should be less tough and are generally more viscid. Microscopically the relative short basidia and the dextrinoid tramal tissue should identify it as a Marasmius.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Most common in southern California, but it has been recorded as far north as Oakland.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: In southern California this species is typically found in live oak (Quercus agrifolia) leaf duff. Interestingly the one observation from we have from northern California was under cypress.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: Marasmius oreades and some Hygrophorus s.l. species. See Diagnostic Description for more details.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: I have heard that this species was commonly eaten by the native peoples of southern California, but I need to find a real reference.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Myriostoma coliforme (Dicks.) Corda (1842)

Commonly called the Saltshaker earthstar, or in some areas, the Pepper Pot.

This fungus features a roundish ball called a head or a peridium containing spores. This ball sits on small stalks on top of star-like rays. When immature or dry, the rays (also called the outer peridium or exoperidium) enclose the endoperidium (inner peridium). When the basidiocarp gets wet, the exoperidium splits and folds back, forming the star-shaped structure. The inner peridium remains closed and this is where the spores are formed.

Unlike true puffballs, the basidia where the spores grow are not arranged in a hymenium. Instead the basidia form throughout the entire inside of the head. This spore mass is called the gleba. The gleba becomes powdery with age and the spores are dispersed through holes in the peridium called mouths or pores.

When the mushroom gets dry the star-like rays will fold back up around the endoperidium until it rains again, then they fold back out and the rain droplets can hit the walls of the endoperidium. The force of the droplets ejects spores out of the pores. This behavior allows the fungus to disperse its spores during moist conditions which increases the chance that they will be able to germinate.

Etymology: From Latin, “like a colander”

Previously known as:
Lycoperdon coliforme Dicks. (1776)
Geastrum coliformis (Dicks.) Pers. (1801)

(Taxonomy from Index Fungorum )

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Endoperidium: 1.5-7 cm wide, papery, spherical, sometimes flattened. Features several pores or mouths on upper surface which is grayish brown in color. Gleba is white when young, becoming brown and powdery with age, divided into loculi, each of which opens into an ostiole to release spores. Capillitial threads are free and simple.

Stalk: Several short, small stalks connect inner peridium to outer peridium.

Exoperidium: usually 5 to 12 rays, 1-6 cm long, light brown to brownish gray in color. Covering the endoperidium when young, splitting into rays with maturity, and opening/expanding when wet. Exoperidium is actually two layers, the upper layer being the mesoperidium. These two layers don’t easily separate and sometimes are indistinguishable.

Spores: Reddish-brown, spherical, heavily warted, 4-6 um in diameter.

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Widely distributed in North America. Also reported from South America and Europe, most likely found in other parts of the world as well. Most sources indicate that this species is rare. It is the only species in the genus Myriostoma.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Likes to grow in dry woodlands, and in sandy soil in open areas. Solitary or in small groups.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Several Geastrum and Astraeus earthstars look similar. However, Myriostoma coliforme is the only earthstar that has many mouths on the inner peridium, so this is the most distinguishing characteristic to use to separate it from the others. It also is the only earthstar that features several short stalks connecting its inner and outer peridiums (other earthstars sometimes have one stalk, but never several).

See Tom Volk’s page on earthstars.

When young, before the outer peridium has split open, earthstars can resemble puffballs. Myriostoma features 3 peridial layers (the mesoperidium is often inseparable from the exoperidium, but is usually distinct), where as true puffballs only have 2 peridial layers. Also, true puffballs feature basidia arranged in a hymenium, and their spores are usually smooth.

See Tom Volk’s page on puffballs.

dataObject.dc:title: Uses
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Can be used for decoration because of its aesthetically pleasing appearance. It also plays important roles in the environment, although its exact ecological niche has not been determined with certainty.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Powdery Sea-Fog Lichen

Scraggly fruticose lichen growing on bark near ocean, with antler-like cylindrical branches and scattered bluish-grayish powdery clumps.

!image 24086!

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Pacific coast of North America from Baja to southern Alaska.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
This can readily be distinguished from all other Niebla spp. in North America by its conspicuous bluish powdery soralia. Only one other species grows on trees, N. ceruchis from southern California and Baja California.

Species of Ramalina have flattened branches or are distinctly beard-like and pendulous.

Species of Usnea are more well-branched, with fine terminal branchlets or fibrils, and all Usnea contain a stretchy rubber-band-like central cord.

Species of Evernia and Pseudevernia have flattened branches and never as smooth.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Angel-Hair Sea Fog Lichen

Small fruticose lichen forming compact Cladina-like cushions on coastal bluffs of California and Baja California. Branches are well-branched and relatively fine and delicate, often with pointed black tips. Apothecia are uncommon.

!image 24127!

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: On rocks on coastal bluffs and cliffs, rarely soil.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: The only other shrubby fruticose lichens on coastal bluffs are other species of Niebla. Only one other species has such fine densely caespitose branches, N. tuberculata, which is endemic to the Morro Bay area, is tuberculate and isidiate-papillate (often black-tipped), and has an overall coarser appearance.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Bouquet Sea-Fog Lichen

Small shrubby fruticose lichen on rocks on coastal bluffs and cliffs. The branches are short and stubby, with abundant clumps of terminal apothecia making it look like a tiny bouquet of flowers.

!image 24122!

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Rocks on coastal bluffs and cliffs, apparently never on soil.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
The only fruticose lichens on coastal rocks likely to be confused with this species are other Niebla spp.:

N. homalea branches more flattened and longer, with a more scraggly overall habit
N. laevigata branches distinctly flattened and smooth
N. cephalota rarely on rock, sorediate
N. robusta inflated, spongy branches
N. procera much longer branches
N. ceruchoides densely-branched

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Armored Sea-Fog Lichen

Common shrubby fruticose lichen on rocks on bluffs and cliffs overlooking sea. Branches have a distinctive angular appearance making it look like it’s covered with plates of armor. It is a highly-variable species, in size, amount of branching, number of apothecia, amount of cracking, and even chemistry.

!image 24097!

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
The technical character most important in separating this species from other Niebla spp. is the presence of chondroid strands in the medulla. These are visible, even with a hand lans in the field, by cutting a thick branch cross-wise: the strands appear as irregular to rounded thickenings in the otherwise white-cottony (though still very dense) medulla. (See image 24098.)

!image 24098!

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Throughout coastal California and Baja Caifornia. I’ve found it thriving as far north as Point Navarro, in Mendocino County, and expect it can be found farther north as well.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Rocks along immediate coast on bluffs and cliffs. Also found in sand or soil on the islands of southern and Baja California, as well as the mainland in central Baja California. (Note, soil populations have a somewhat different morphology, turning into tumbleweed-like things apparently.)

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Since this and other species of Niebla are often rather variable, there are a number of look-alikes that are tricky to separate.

N. josecuervoi from Baja California is most difficult. See Nash’s Sonoran Flora for an exhaustive discussion of these two nearly-identical species.

N. laevigata is shinier, smoother, flatter, and lacks chondroid strands in the medulla. The two often occur together and share a similarly broad range into northern California.

N. isidiascens is conspicuously isidiate with coralloid isidia.

N. combeoides often also has an angular appearance, however the branches are generally much shorter and stubbier, and never as flattened. It typically forms little “bouquets” with clumps of strictly terminal apothecia, while N. homalea has less frequent and often marginal apothecia.

N. polymorpha is supposedly more irregular, but in particular lacks the chondroid strands of N. homalea.

N. robusta is inflated and spongy.

The rest are obviously different, mostly with rounded branches, among other differences.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Smooth or Black-Footed Sea-Fog Lichen

Shrubby fruticose lichen on rocks of sea bluffs and cliffs. The branches are conspicuously flattened, smooth and shiny, like blades.

!image 24115!

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
The most important technical character distinguishing this from the similar N. homalea is the lack of chondroid strands in the medulla. This can be seen in the field with a hand lense by cutting a branch cross-wise: chondroid strands would appear as irregular to rounded somewhat shiny thickenings in the otherwise cottony white (but still rather dense) medulla.

!image 24117!

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Throughout coastal California and Baja Caifornia. I’ve found it thriving as far north as Point Navarro, in Mendocino County, and expect it can be found farther north as well.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Rocks along immediate coast on bluffs and cliffs, apparently never soil. Always growing with N. homalea in my experience.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: The only Niebla that ever attains such broad flattened smooth blade-like branches is N. homalea, which has chondroid strands in the medulla, but is generally more angular, duller and less flattened.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Antler Sea-Fog Lichen

Antler-shaped fruticose lichen on rocks on sea bluffs and cliffs. The branches are rounded, pointed, loosely-branched, often with black splotches (maculae) and circumferential cracks.

!image 24119!

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Throughout coastal southern and Baja Caifornia. I’ve found it as far north as Point Lobos state Park near Monterey.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Rocks along immediate coast on bluffs and cliffs, apparently never on soil.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
This is rather distinctive among the Niebla, with only N. cedrosensis being very similar.

N. cedrosensis is duller, lacks black splotches, with blunter tips. It is restricted to the islands and a few places on mainland Baja.

N. ceruchoides and N. tuberculata have much finer and more intricately-branched branches, the latter with isiose-papillae as well.

N. combeoides has stubby, unbranched, often more angular branches, with abundant terminal apothecia.

N. homalea and the rest have flattened or irregularly-angular branches.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Sea Fog Lichens
Family: Ramalinaceae

Shrubby lichens, typically growing on rocks within stone’s throw of the ocean. They occur only in the dry fog-belt of mediterranean climates, such as California and Baja California. In these habitats, they are the only large shrubby macrolichens that grow on the wind-swept, highly-exposed bluffs overlooking the sea.

One species, Niebla cephalota grows on trees, and extends both much farther inland and farther north all the way into southern Alaska(!). This is also the only sorediate species.

Key to Species in California

(This extracted from Lichen Flora of the Greater Sonoran Desert Region, Vol. II, Nash et al. 2004, genus treatment by P. A. Bowler and J. E. Marsh.)

1. on bark or wood
2. powdery soredia . . . N. cephalota
2. not sorediate . . . . . . N. ceruchis
1. on rock, rarely soil
3. branches flattened or angular in cross-section
4. chondroid strands present in medulla (check cross-section with hand lens)
5. not isidiate, very common . . . . . . . . . . N. homalea
5. conspicuously coralloid isidiate . . . . . . N. isidiascens
4. medulla with uniform texture
6. branches strongly flattened and smooth . . . . N. laevigata
6. branches irregularly thickened and rough . . . N. polymorpha
3. branches rounded in cross-section
7. branches long (to 8 cm) and spreading to subpendulose . . . N. procera
7. branches short (less than 3 cm) and densely caespitose
8. branches stout and rarely branched
9. branches inflated and spongy . . . . . . N. robusta
9. branches stubby and solid . . . . . . . . . N. combeoides
8. branches very thin and well-branched, forming Cladina-like cushions
10. smooth, forming dense Cladina-like cushions . . . . N. ceruchoides
10. isidiate-papillate, coarser, Morro Bay . . . . . . . . . N. tuberculata

Additional species in Baja Caifornia:

N. josecuervoi like N. homalea but with different chemistry
N. cedrosensis like N. procera but not black-splotched and duller

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
BRANCHES: solid, generally flattened or at least angular, pale yellowish- to grayish-green, often cracked, often black-spotted
CORTEX: thick, rigid, from anticlinal or palisade layer to simple sheath grading into thick underlying cortex
MEDULLA: loose to dense, hyphal strands often sticking together, occ. forming strands
APOTHECIA: discs; spores 1-septate, hyaline, straight or bent
PYCNIDIA: black, immersed, conidia rod-shaped
CHEMISTRY: cortex KC+ gold (usnic acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Immediate coast from south Alaska to Baja California, southwestern Europe and Canary Islands, northern Chile, and south Africa.

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Mainly maritime rock outcrops, occ. soil or trees.

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Ramalina can be similar, especially for tree-dwelling forms. It, however, has pale pycnidia, pseudocyphellae, prosoplectenchymatous cortex, and bacilliform conidia.

Vermilicinia is a segregate genus not yet fully accepted. See the discussion in Ramalinaceae.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: African Saucer Lichen

Whitish rough crust lichen with large thick-rimmed heavily-pruinose apothecia on bark.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: grayish to somewhat yellowish, verruculose, shiny
APOTHECIA: 0.6-2.0(-2.7) mm, margin thin, disc yellowish-pinkish-orangish and heavily white pruinose
SPORES: 8 per ascus, 29-45 × 19-28 µm
CHEMISTRY: disc and medulla under apothecia C+ and KC+ red (gyrophoric acid); thallus UV+ yellow (lichexanthone)

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Smooth Saucer Lichen

Thin smooth whitish crust lichen with large thick-rimmed apothecia on deciduous trees.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: very thin, smooth, whitish to pinkish or yellowish gray
APOTHECIA: to 3 mm; disc pale orange, epruinose; margin thick and smooth
SPORES: ???
CHEMISTRY: disc, margin, and parts of medulla C+ and KC+ red (gyrophoric and olivetoric acids)

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Double-Rimmed Saucer Lichen

Rough whitish crustose lichen with large thick-rimmed pinkish apothecia on conifer bark.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: creamy white, rough to verrucose
APOTHECIA: up to 4 mm, double-margins (thalline outer and disc-colored inner),
disc pinkish, epruinose, no algae or algae spotty below apothecium
SPORES: ???
CHEMISTRY: thallus and rims C+ and KC+ red (gyrophoric acid), medulla C-

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: O. subpallescens is very similar but lacks the inner excipular ring, and has a continuous algal layer below the apothecium.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Rough, whitish crustose lichen on coastal rocks, with big thick-rimmed pinkish apothecia.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: whitish, smooth to rugose
APOTHECIA: round, 0.75-2.0 mm; disc pinkish, heavily white pruinose
SPORES: 8 spores, 45-65(-88) x 25-40(-50) µm
CHEMISTRY: thallus KC+ yellow (variolic acid?), disc C+ and KC+ red (gyrophoric acid)

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Acidic to slightly basic rocks in humid, often coastal habitats.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Saucer Lichens

Gray, crustose lichens with large beautiful saucer or donut-shaped adnate apothecia.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: gray to white, thin to thick, smooth to verrucose
APOTHECIA: rim thalline and well-developed, occ. with inner excipular ring; disc yellowish to pinkish to orangish, often broad, often pruinose
ASCI: thick-walled, K/I+ dark blue, Pertusaria-like
SPORE: 2-8 per ascus, simple, gen. more than 20 µm long, thick-walled (but thinner than Pertusaria and Varicellaria)

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
Pertusaria has thicker spore walls (> one sixth the total width of the spore), often in two layers, and less well-developed apothecial margins (apothecia often immersed in thalline warts).

Lecanora has smaller spores and less well-developed apothecial margins.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Common Name: Saucer Lichen

Whitish rough crustose lichen with big thick-margined yellow-orange apothecia, on bark.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: whitish, verruculose
APOTHECIA: large; rims thick, even, smooth; disc yellow-orange, epruinose
SPORES: 8 per ascus, (35-)40-58 × 20-31 µm
CHEMISTRY: cortex, rim, and disc all C+ and KC+ red (gyrophoric acid); all tissues UV-

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Asia, Brazil, Australia, and west coast North America (from Haida Gwaii to southern California).

dataObject.dc:title: Habitat
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: On bark of deciduous trees, to 1550 m.

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Smooth, thin, whitish crustose lichen, with big, beautiful donut-shaped, heavily-pruinose apothecia.

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
THALLUS: thin, smooth, whitish
APOTHECIA: thalline rims smooth, thick, even; disc pinkish, heavily pruinose
SPORES: 4 per ascus, large, hyaline, simple
CHEMISTRY: all C-

dataObject.dc:title: Look Alikes
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
No other genus has such thick, well-developed apothecial margins (see Lecanora, for example). Pertusaria also has large spores, but they are more thick-walled, often multi-layered.

Among Orcholechia, many look superficially similar, but chemistry separates it from most:

O. farinacea also C-, but has a thick, verrucose thallus
O. juvenalis C+ red disc, thallus thick
O. subathallina C+ red disc, thallus thin
O. montana C+ pink/red rim, smaller apothecia
O. subpallescens C+ pink/red rim, coastal
O. oregonensis C+ pink/red rim, thallus also C+ red
O. laevigata C+ pink/red rim, thallus C-, algal layer discontinuous
O. trochophora C+ pink/red rim, thallus C-, algal layer continuous

dataObject.dc:title: General Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Family: Ophioparmaceae

Crustose lichens with distinctive deep brownish-red apothecia (from haemoventosin).

dataObject.dc:title: Diagnostic Description
dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
APOTHECIA: deep brownish-red from haemoventosin crystals in epihymenium, pigment turns distinctive K+ blue-violet
ASCI: uniformly K/I+ blue thollus
SPORES: 8 per ascus, hyaline, simple to multiply transversely-septate, spirally twisted in ascus

dataObject.dc:title: Distribution
